item.title: [AVRO-120] specific and reflect APIs handle packages poorly
item.description: The specific and reflect APIs require applications to manually specify a Java package name. Classes used within a protocol or schema must all be in that single Java package. Rather, both should determine package names from a schema namespaces and from Java class packages.
item.summary: specific and reflect APIs handle packages poorly

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
The attached patch:

  • removes all explicit package-name specification from public APIs, instead package names are retrieved either from the schema or from a Java class.
  • changes the protocol compiler to generate separate files per class, rather than using classes nested within the interface. this permits the generated classes to be in the same package as the interface or different packages, however it's specified in the protocol.
  • fix schema/protocol parser/renderer to correctly default namespaces
Unless there are objections, I will commit this shortly.

Here's an updated patch. This also fixes Schema and Protocol to correctly handle multiple namespaces and adds tests for this.

In particular, names may now be specified with a <namespace>.<name> notation. This permits one to refer to schemas in a namespace other than the default namespace. The default namespace is specified in the top-level schema or protocol.

I will commit this in a day or so if no one objects.

item.title: [AVRO-121] expected schema should be specifiable by specific & reflect datum readers
item.description: The generic datum reader supports the specification of an 'expected' schema, that may differ from that used to write the data. The specific and reflect datum readers are based on the generic, but do not permit the specification of this and hence cannot support reading alternate versions of data.
item.summary: expected schema should be specifiable by specific & reflect datum readers

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Adds a setExpected(Schema) method. Also, when the single-schema constructor is used, the expected schema now defaults to that passed in. This means that, when a so-constructed datum reader is passed to a container (e.g., a DataFileReader), and setSchema(Schema) is called with the schema used to write the container, the schema used in the constructor will be used as the "expected" schema, as intended.
I just committed this.

item.title: [AVRO-122] ivy task does not enjoy being defined twice (build error)
item.description:
This same issue exists in ZOOKEEPER-535
---------------
Ant resolves the same dependencies multiple times if multiple targets are run on the command line:

"ant b c", where b and c both depend on a, results in a being executed twice. However if you have a
target d which depends on both b and c, "ant d" will only result in a being executed once.

say "ant compile-java compile-java-test" is run, this will currently fail as ivy-init is run twice, resulting in the taskdef failing.

Rather we need a guard on the ivy-init target itself to ensure it isn't run twice.

ie: put an unless attrib on ivy-init, then set that property in the body of the target
item.summary: ivy task does not enjoy being defined twice (build error)

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: This patch puts a guard on ivy-init task (it will only be run once)
I just committed this. Thanks, Pat!

item.title: [AVRO-124] avro release artifact includes ivy jar file but no license
item.description:
The release artifact includes the ivy jar, but no license file, notice, etc...

I believe that you don't intend to ship this, but it snuck into the release based on it being in the lib directory? (esp since the build.xml will d/l the jar if it's missing)

You probably just need to explicitly exclude it when building the release package (see ZooKeeper build.xml, I found the same issue there when moving to ivy)
item.summary: avro release artifact includes ivy jar file but no license

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
I'd currently intended to include all of the dependent jar files in the release, so that the release can be used standalone & offline, without folks having to locate dependencies, with Ivy or otherwise. Given that, the lack of an Ivy license file is an oversight. It's under the AL2, so the top-level license covers us legally, but, by convention, we're including the license files for other AL2 stuff in lib and should be consistent. Does that make sense?

Ideally we should probably configure Ivy so that it looks in the lib/ directory for dependencies so that offline builds work when a release is first unpacked. I just tried to configure that but failed to find a simple way to do it yet...

Makes sense. However I was thinking, why is ivy necessary to the end user (vs contributor)? You have avro/zk jar, + the dependent jars, ivy jar is really only necessary if you want to build yourself, and/or test, etc... (am I missing something?) For testing you need to pull down jars anyway, so really not having ivy would only limit you to not recompiling (if you are offline). Therefore my assumption that you didn't really intend to include. But, like I said, what you are saying sounds fine to me as well.
I just committed this.
